segment.source: Submit a work item to the thread pool
segment.target: Submit a work item to the thread pool

segment.source: Learn how to do work in a separate thread by submitting a work item to the thread pool.
segment.target: Learn how to do work in a separate thread by submitting a work item to the thread pool.

segment.source: Submit a work item to the thread pool
segment.target: Submit a work item to the thread pool

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: RunAsync
segment.target: RunAsync

segment.source: IAsyncAction
segment.target: IAsyncAction

segment.source: Learn how to do work in a separate thread by submitting a work item to the thread pool.
segment.target: Learn how to do work in a separate thread by submitting a work item to the thread pool.

segment.source: Use this to maintain a responsive UI while still completing work that takes a noticeable amount of time, and use it to complete multiple tasks in parallel.
segment.target: Use this to maintain a responsive UI while still completing work that takes a noticeable amount of time, and use it to complete multiple tasks in parallel.

segment.source: Create and submit the work item
segment.target: Create and submit the work item

segment.source: Create a work item by calling RunAsync.
segment.target: Create a work item by calling RunAsync.

segment.source: Supply a delegate to do the work (you can use a lambda, or a delegate function).
segment.target: Supply a delegate to do the work (you can use a lambda, or a delegate function).

segment.source: Note that RunAsync returns an IAsyncAction object; store this object for use in the next step.
segment.target: Note that RunAsync returns an IAsyncAction object; store this object for use in the next step.

segment.source: Three versions of RunAsync are available so that you can optionally specify the priority of the work item, and control whether it runs concurrently with other work items.
segment.target: Three versions of RunAsync are available so that you can optionally specify the priority of the work item, and control whether it runs concurrently with other work items.

segment.source: Note Use CoreDispatcher.RunAsync to access the UI thread and show progress from the work item.
segment.target: Note Use CoreDispatcher.RunAsync to access the UI thread and show progress from the work item.

segment.source: The following example creates a work item and supplies a lambda to do the work:
segment.target: The following example creates a work item and supplies a lambda to do the work:

segment.source: Following the call to RunAsync, the work item is queued by the thread pool and runs when a thread becomes available.
segment.target: Following the call to RunAsync, the work item is queued by the thread pool and runs when a thread becomes available.

segment.source: Thread pool work items run asynchronously and they can run in any order, so make sure your work items function independently.
segment.target: Thread pool work items run asynchronously and they can run in any order, so make sure your work items function independently.

segment.source: Note that the work item checks the IAsyncInfo.Status property, and exits if the work item is cancelled.
segment.target: Note that the work item checks the IAsyncInfo.Status property, and exits if the work item is cancelled.

segment.source: Handle work item completion
segment.target: Handle work item completion

segment.source: Provide a completion handler by setting the IAsyncAction.Completed property of the work item.
segment.target: Provide a completion handler by setting the IAsyncAction.Completed property of the work item.

segment.source: Supply a delegate (you can use a lambda or a delegate function) to handle work item completion.
segment.target: Supply a delegate (you can use a lambda or a delegate function) to handle work item completion.

segment.source: For example, use CoreDispatcher.RunAsync to access the UI thread and show the result.
segment.target: For example, use CoreDispatcher.RunAsync to access the UI thread and show the result.

segment.source: The following example updates the UI with the result of the work item submitted in step 1:
segment.target: The following example updates the UI with the result of the work item submitted in step 1:

segment.source: Note that the completion handler checks whether the work item was cancelled before dispatching a UI update.
segment.target: Note that the completion handler checks whether the work item was cancelled before dispatching a UI update.

segment.source: Summary and next steps
segment.target: Summary and next steps

segment.source: You can learn more by downloading the code from this quickstart in the Creating a ThreadPool work item sample written for Windows 8.1, and re-using the source code in a win\_unap Windows 10 app.
segment.target: You can learn more by downloading the code from this quickstart in the Creating a ThreadPool work item sample written for Windows 8.1, and re-using the source code in a win\_unap Windows 10 app.
